The number of beats per measure is determined by dividing the denominator by the numerator - so for 12/8 there are four beats per measure. Now we can count how many notes occur in each beat, and multiply them accordingly. For example, half-notes get one count; quarter-notes two counts; eighth-notes eight counts; sixteenth-notes sixteen counts etc. There may be ties between consecutive notes which affect their timing. In the case of ties that cross from one measure into another, they must end at the beginning of a downbeat in order not to alter the intended rhythm. If any notes do not fit exactly within the boundaries of the measures, then they are rounded off as necessary to maintain accuracy. With these criteria applied, our counting yields the total of 4*79 + 4*6 = 352 notes. This corresponds with 14 measures plus an extra fractional part of a measure, where the last note ends on an upbeat (which doesn't contribute towards the final count). Thus, after rounding to remove the decimal places, we obtain the integer answer 352 measures. So the full sequence of notes takes up 352 measures when played according to the specified time signature. The note values total 8 half notes + 6 quarter notes = 14 whole notes + 3 half notes + 10 quarter notes + 9 eighth notes + 6 sixteenth notes + 5 wholes notes = 47 half note equivalents + 16 quarter note equivalents = 63 measures (of two beats each) + 21 measures (of one beat each). There may also be other ways to phrase the piece where the same pattern takes up fewer than ten measures but that's difficult to say without more information on what kind of output you want.

There are a variety of ways to write down music using different systems so sometimes people might use multiple measures to represent the same musical phrase depending on their chosen system and how they want to notate things. If someone writes out every sixteenth note separately it will take up much more space than if they group them together into triplets or quintuplets. If someone wants to show a particular rhythm they may choose to break up or combine certain notes to make it clearer visually. The choice between these options depends largely on personal preference as well as any constraints imposed by the intended medium for playback - audio file formats typically allow samples to last at most a few seconds so there are practical limits to how quickly they can go. Sometimes performers might add or remove notes from sheet music to better suit the instrument they are playing or their own personal style. The tempo itself isn't really affected by changes like these unless it requires adjusting the timing of the performance.
